title: Lightsout grades
body:
Prog 10 (lightsout) is graded. The grades are posted on the course web page. Click on the "Grades" menu, authenticate, and you'll see your grades for this homework, and a projection for future assessments. This is a good way to get a sense of where you are headed in the course, and take action if it does not match your expectations. The "Participation" entry accounts for all quizzes and labs up to today. Here are some statistics, normalized as percentages: 
Max     100.0% Min\t  0.0% Avg      86.5% Median  100.0% StdDev   24.1
You can access test outcomes on Autolab. Note: some people got 0 because they ran out of grace days. In one case this was an Autolab mistake; if you believe Autolab made a mistake in your case too, email me. We do occasionally make mistakes. If you feel we incorrectly graded a question, you have 5 days from now to submit an appeal using the grade appeal procedure on the course web page. We will not consider email or oral requests. #pin

title: TA Applications
body: For those of you interested in applying to be a TA, the application(s) can be found at: - https://www.ugrad.cs.cmu.edu/ta/F17/ (Fall) - https://www.ugrad.cs.cmu.edu/ta/N17/ (Summer II) Note: we generally don't hire students as TAs the semester after they took 15-122 (we prefer to let the concepts gel for at least a semester). Said that, feel free to apply and we'll see how things pan out. #pin

title: Carnival homework schedule
body: As you are probably aware of, Carnival starts on Thursday April 20th. But Thursdays are when programming assignments are typically due. In the past, when we kept it that way, we had a lot of unhappy people working on their code while everybody else was having a good time. To avoid this, in recent years we have been shifting the schedule a bit. Namely, for about 2 weeks starting right after midterm 2, written and programming assignments will be swapped (written hw due on Thursdays and programming hw on Mondays). Specifically (major changes are in bold): written 10 is due on Monday April 3 (normal schedule)nothing is due on Thursday April 6 (the day of midterm 2)prog 9 is due on Monday April 10written 11 is due on Thursday April 13prog 10 is due on Monday April 17written 12 is due on Monday April 24 (back to normal schedule)prog 11(a) is due on Thursday April 27 (back to normal schedule) After that, the schedule is normal again. See the hw schedule on the course web page for details #pin

title: ht_insert fail conditions
body: Autolab gives me the following output for task 4:  Test board-ht-grade-d add_repeated1, expect assertion failure  *** TEST FAILED! Expected a contract to fail. *** Actual outcome: Your program ran to completion, but should have signaled an error or failed a contract *** Hint: Tests that ht_insert fails if you add a struct containing a board already in the table  I don't understand this response. Is ht_insert supposed to fail tests when a duplicate is inserted?  As I read the writeup, if ht_insert is passed a board which has the same bitvector representation as a board already stored, it will call hdict_insert which will update the value at whatever the key hashes to and return a pointer to the old board, which we then free because it is no longer in use. title: Confused about board-ht.h
body: So struct board_data is defined in board-ht.h but it isn't included when we compile the program. Then how would we access the information along with a board?  My idea of solving the problem is something like this, each time you see a new board, you record this board, together with the steps you took to get to this board, in the hash table. And once we see a lights out board, we return the steps that lead to turning all the lights out (i.e. the 'solution'). I'm just confused how we can still do that without being to explicitly accessing the steps, which I thought can be an extra field in struct board_data. int light_solver(queue_t Q, uint8_t width, uint8_t height) { \tREQUIRES(!queue_empty(Q)); \tsize_t c = 0x0000FFFF; \thdict_t HT = ht_new(c);  \twhile(!queue_empty(Q)) \t{ \t\tbitvector* B = (bitvector*) deq(Q);  \t\tuint32_t row; uint32_t col; \t\tfor (row = 0; row < height; row++) { \t\t\tfor (col = 0; col < width; col++)  { \t\t\t\tint i = get_index(row, col, width, height); \t\t\t\tbitvector N = bitvector_flip(*B, i);   \t\t\t\tif(N == 0) { \t\t\t\t\tfree(B); \t\t\t\t\tfree_all(Q, HT); \t\t\t\t\treturn 0; \t\t\t\t} \t\t\t\tvoid *M = ht_lookup(HT, N); \t\t\t\tif(M == NULL) { \t\t\t\t\tstruct board_data *BD = xmalloc(sizeof(struct board_data)); \t\t\t\t\tBD->board = N; \t\t\t\t\tbitvector *b = xmalloc(sizeof(bitvector)); \t\t\t\t\t*b = (BD->board); \t\t\t\t\tenq(Q, (void*) b); \t\t\t\t\tht_insert(HT, (void*) BD); \t\t\t\t} \t\t\t} \t\t} \t} \tfree_all(Q, HT); \treturn 1; }

body: I have written the following code for board-ht.c and I have also written a test file but my ht_insert function's precondition is failing. cam you please help me identify my error.  #include <stdlib.h> // Standard C library: free(), NULL...  #include <stdbool.h> // Standard true, false, and bool type  #include "lib/contracts.h" // Our contracts library  #include "lib/xalloc.h" // Our allocation library  #include "board-ht.h" // The board interface #include "lib/bitvector.h" // The bitvector interface #include "lib/hdict.h" // The bitvector interface #include <stdint.h> typedef struct board_data* board_t; bool key_equal(hdict_key x, hdict_key y) {  REQUIRES(x!=NULL);  REQUIRES(y!=NULL); bitvector* b1=(bitvector*)x;  bitvector* b2=(bitvector*)y;  return bitvector_equal(*b1, *b2); } size_t hash(bitvector x) {  x = ((x >> 12) ^ x) * 0x45d9f3b;  x = ((x >> 12) ^ x) * 0x45d9f3b;  x = (x >> 12) ^ x;  return abs(x); } size_t key_hash(hdict_key x) {  REQUIRES(x!=NULL);  bitvector* b1=(bitvector*)x;  return hash(*b1); } void value_free(hdict_value x) {  REQUIRES(x!=NULL);  board_t B1=(board_t)x;  free((void*)B1); } hdict_t ht_new(size_t capacity)  /*@requires capacity > 0; @*/  /*@ensures \\result != NULL; @*/  {  REQUIRES(capacity > 0); hdict_t D=hdict_new(capacity,&key_equal,&key_hash,&value_free);  ENSURES(D!=NULL);  return D; } /* ht_lookup(H,B) returns   * NULL if no struct containing the board B exists in H  * A struct containing the board B if one exists in H.  */ struct board_data *ht_lookup(hdict_t H, bitvector B)  /*@requires H != NULL; @*/  {  REQUIRES(H != NULL);  bitvector* b1=xmalloc(sizeof(bitvector));  *b1=B;  hdict_value val=hdict_lookup(H, (void*)b1);  if(val!=NULL){  free(b1);  return (board_t)val;  }  free(b1);  printf("i am here \ ");  return NULL; } /* ht_insert(H,e) has no return value, because it should have as  * a precondition that no struct currently in the hashtable contains  * the same board as DAT->board.  */ void ht_insert(hdict_t H, struct board_data *DAT)  /*@requires H != NULL; @*/  { REQUIRES(H != NULL && ht_lookup(H,DAT->board)==NULL);  bitvector* b1=xmalloc(sizeof(bitvector));  *b1=DAT->board;  hdict_insert(H, (void*)b1, (void*)DAT);  free(b1); }  the test file is the following  #include <stdlib.h> // Standard C library: free(), NULL...  #include <stdbool.h> // Standard true, false, and bool type  #include "lib/contracts.h" // Our contracts library  #include "lib/xalloc.h" // Our allocation library  #include "board-ht.h" // The board interface #include "lib/bitvector.h" // The bitvector interface #include "lib/hdict.h" // The bitvector interface #include <stdint.h> typedef struct board_data* board_t;  int main(){  hdict_t D=ht_new(10);  board_t B1=xmalloc(sizeof(struct board_data));  board_t B2=xmalloc(sizeof(struct board_data)); bitvector b1=bitvector_new();  printf("pos1\ ");  bitvector b2=bitvector_new(); for(uint8_t i=0;i<32;i++){  b1=bitvector_flip(b1,i);  }  printf("pos2\ ");  for(uint8_t i=0;i<32;i++){  b2=bitvector_flip(b2,i);  } B1->board=b1;  B2->board=b2;  B1->test=32;  B2->test=32; printf("pos3\ ");  board_t temp1=ht_lookup(D, b1);  printf("pos4\ ");  board_t temp2=ht_lookup(D, b2);  printf("pos5\ "); ASSERT(temp1==NULL);  ASSERT(temp2==NULL);  printf("pos6\ "); ht_insert(D, B1);  ht_insert(D, B2); printf("pos7\ ");  temp1=ht_lookup(D, b1);  temp2=ht_lookup(D, b2);  printf("pos8\ "); ASSERT(temp1!=NULL);  printf("pos9\ ");  ASSERT(temp2!=NULL);  printf("pos10\ ");  ASSERT(temp1->test==32);  ASSERT(temp2->test==32);  printf("pos11\ ");  ASSERT((temp1->board)==b1);  printf("pos12\ ");  ASSERT((temp2->board)==b2); return 0; }

title: A Pointer For Task 3
body:
I experienced huge confusion about why I failed the "big" tests, but found a useful pointer in the course notes: When you add, subtract, multiply, divide, compare, or do bitwise operations involving multiple variables, it s best to make sure that all the numbers you re working with have the same size and same signedness. One important gotcha here: if you just write the num- ber 4, it s treated as an int by default, so writing 
  int64_t i = 1 << 40;
will actually be undefined behavior, because 1 is (implementation- defined to be) a 32-bit quantity that can only be shifted by numbers between 0 and 31, inclusive. The fix, in this situation, is to write: 
  int64_t i = 1;   i = i << 40;

    return (start -> next == NULL && i == 1);   }   // recursive case   else   {     //println("base3");     return is_inclusive_segment(start->next, end, i-1);   }  }  bool is_queue(queue* Q)  {   //println("is_queue");   if (Q == NULL) return false;   //println("is_queue_1");   return is_inclusive_segment(Q->front, Q->back, Q->size); }  queue_t queue_new() {   //println("queue_new");   struct queue_header *new = xmalloc(sizeof(struct queue_header));   new -> front = NULL;   new -> size = 0;   ENSURES(new != NULL);   ENSURES(is_queue(new));   return new; }  size_t queue_size(queue_t Q)  {   //println("queue_size");   REQUIRES(is_queue(Q));   //ENSURES(Q->size >= 0);   return Q->size; }  void enq(queue_t Q, void* x)  {   //println("enq");   REQUIRES(is_queue(Q));   list *l = xmalloc(sizeof(list));   l -> next = NULL;   l -> data = x;   if (Q -> size == 0)   {     //println("enq5");     Q -> front = l;     //println("enq6");     Q -> back = l;     //println("enq7");   }   else   {     //println("enq1");     Q -> back -> next = l;     Q -> back = l;   }   Q -> size += 1;   ENSURES(is_queue(Q)); }  void* deq(queue_t Q) {   //println("deq");   REQUIRES(is_queue(Q));   REQUIRES(queue_size(Q) > 0);   list* res = Q->front;   Q -> front = Q -> front -> next;   Q -> size -= 1;   void* data = res->data;   free(res);   //ENSURES(is_queue(Q));   return data; }  void* queue_peek(queue_t Q, size_t i) {   //println("peek");   REQUIRES(is_queue(Q));   //REQUIRES(0 <= i && i < queue_size(Q));   list* curr = Q -> front;   if (i == 0) return curr->data;   else   {     for (size_t c = 0; c < i; c++)     {       curr = curr -> next;     }     return curr -> data;   } }  void queue_reverse(queue_t Q) {   //println("reverse");   REQUIRES(is_queue(Q));   if (Q->front == NULL) return;   list* A = Q -> front -> next;   list* back_next = Q -> back -> next;   Q -> back = Q -> front;   Q -> front -> next = back_next;   while (A != back_next)   {     list* B = A->next; i < Q->size; i++)     {       base_val = (*F)(base_val, start_node->data);       start_node = start_node->next;     }     //println("queue_iterate_done");     return base_val;   } }  void queue_free(queue_t Q, elem_free_fn* F) {   REQUIRES(is_queue(Q)); Max    100.0% Min\t39.6% Avg     81.6% Median  84.4% StdDev  12.9

title: Written 10 Question 3.1 (a)
body:
While grading question 3.1 (a) on the most recent written homework, we came across a lot of common missteps that should be acknowledged/corrected: If you're still confused about these or any other concepts, there are office hours in GHC 4307 until 10 pm tonight (Tues) as well as the same location from 8 - 10 pm Wednesday. (6-8pm O.H. are replaced by the review session, in Rashid Auditorium) Casting a struct pointer before accessing a field The arrow operator (->), which accesses the field of a struct pointer, has a higher precedence than casting. This means that the expression (report*)x->current_price first tries to get the current_price field of x, then casts the result to a report*. This wouldn't compile, as you can't dereference a void* in c0. To fix this issue, you need parentheses around the cast: 
((report*)x)->current_price
Note: if you're not sure of the order of operations, it's better to be explicit and insert extra parentheses than to guess and get it wrong. In the future, your code may be read by a programmer (maybe even your future self) who isn't certain of the precedence of the operators, so resolving ambiguity is important. Another common misstep was to add an extra dereference, for example (*(report*)x)->current_price. Remember that foo->bar is equivalent to (*foo).bar, so you don't need a star in addition to the arrow, unless you are dereferencing a pointer stored in the struct field. Minheap vs. Maxheap In this question, although we wanted to keep the n largest price increases, you needed a priority function that prioritized smaller price increases. In the first while loop, we want to remove the report from the priority queue that has the smallest price increase. pq_rem removes the highest priority element first, so your priority function needed to assign highest priority to the smallest price increase. Note: Remember that 'higher priority' doesn't imply 'higher value' - priority is an abstract notion that you (the client) define by implementing the priority function which you pass by pointer to pq_new. Why does the priority queue's capacity need to be n + 1? This was particularly tricky. The reason for this was **NOT** because of the unused zeroth index in our heap implementation, but because of a particular edge case in the given algorithm. Since the algorithm specifies that you immediately remove a report whenever the priority queue is full, at the end of the loop you end up with at most (capacity - 1) elements in the priority queue. In order to keep the n largest elements, you needed to have room to store n + 1 elements. You could think of the loop body as doing the following:
    add one element to the priority queueif there are n + 1 elements, drop the smallest so only the n largest remain.

title: lecture 17, complexity of PQs as arrays
body: I wanted to check my understanding about this line on page 5, section 4 of lecture 17: "Typically, when using a priority queue, we expect the number of inserts and deletes to roughly balance.Then neither the unordered nor the ordered array provide a good data structure since a sequence of $$n$$ inserts and deletes will have worst-case complexity O($$n^2$$ )." Does this mean: In an unordered array, if you want to delete $$n$$ elements that you just inserted, for each $$n$$ (which took O(1) time to insert), it takes O($$n$$) deletions so that's O($$n^2$$). But in a sorted array, it takes O($$n$$) time to insert $$n$$ elements, so while removing them takes O(1) time, the whole process already took O($$n^2$$) time. ?

title: Information about midterm 2
body: Some information about the upcoming midterm: It is taking place on Thursday April 6th as follows (building map): Students in lecture 1: 9:00-10:20am Sections A/AA: WEH 5310 Sections B/BB: DH 1211Sections C/CC, D/DD, E/EE, F/FF, G/GG: DH 2315 Students in lecture 2: 10:30-11:50am Sections H/HH: PH 226B Sections I/II: PH 226C Sections J/JJ: PH A18B Sections K/KK, L/LL, M/MM, N/NN: DH 2315 Students with accommodations: I will email you shortly. If you are expecting accommodations and you do not get an email, email me immediately at iliano@cmu.edu Everybody must bring his/her student ID. You MUST arrive on time if you arrive late you will not be given extra time. The exam has a duration of 80 minutes. The topics are pretty much everything we have covered in class since the beginning of the term to Thursday March 30th (included). Looking at the contents of the practice midterms (see course web page), written assignments, labs and recitations will provide you with a good idea of what to expect. We will ask you to write some C0/C1 code, but we won't be picky about minor issues of syntax. We will take points off, however, for invalid contracts. All you can have with you is a single double-sided 8.5" x 11" handwritten cheat sheet: the exam will contain nothing that can be just looked up in your notes or in the handouts, and we will provide you with all the information you need to solve each question. Writing a 1-page cheat sheet is an incredibly effective way of reviewing concepts even if you never end up looking at it. There will be a review session on Wednesday April 5th from 6 to 8pm in GH 4401 (Rashid Auditorium). If you have any doubts, that's a good opportunity to get them resolved.

title: How to Draw Trees/Graphs Online Easily
body: Some Written HWs might ask you to draw graphs after some operations are performed on them. There's an online site that allows you to do this less painfully than drawing or using MS Paint. Should be pretty self explanatory, but: 1) Go to http://madebyevan.com/fsm/ 2) Read the directions on the bottom of the site on how to add, edit, and delete nodes. FOR MAC USERS: You can delete a node by pressing fn + delete. 3) When you're done making your graph, hit the "Export as PNG" button below the white screen, then click "Save image as." Give it a name and destination folder. If you're using LaTeX you have that option as well. 4) After you downloaded it, insert it into whatever PDF editor you're using. http://www.pdfescape.com/ makes this very simple - you can click the "Insert Image" button and then click and drag on your screen to establish the size of the image. Then click on the yellow tab to "disable." 5) You're done and now you have some nice looking and clean graphs.

title: BST_lookup loop invariant
body:
1.d.ii asks us to prove that: 
//@loop_invariant is_ordered(T, lo, hi);
is true initially, however is_bst does not check if the bst is actually ordered, it just checks if it is a tree: 
bool is_bst(bst* B) {     return B!= NULL         && is_tree(B->root); }
so even though the first call of is_ordered will be correct, when is_ordered calls itself recursively it can still fail since we have no guarantee that the is tree is ordered. The lecture code has is_bst defined as: 
bool is_bst(tree* T) {     return is_tree(T)         && is_ordered(T,NULL,NULL); }
So is this the is_bst we should be using?

title: Circularity check seems unnecessary?
body: In Task 1 of Ropes:   why do we even need a circularity check at all?  Three cases: 1) NULL (returning true) 2) It's a leaf, so left and right are both null (no chance for circularity), len has to match length of string.  3) Non-Leaf (only chance for circulairity)... but, Non-leaf's left len and right len must both be > 0 and sum to Non-leaf's len.  This means that left len and right len are both strictly less than non-leaf. It therefore cannot be circular?  I'm confused why we'd even need a circularity check?

title: circularity check
body: In the lecture notes, the circularity check is explained as follows:      "This recursive definition can be directly encoded into a very simple data structure invariant is_tree. It checks very little: just that all the data fields are non-NULL, as the client interface requires. If it terminates, it also ensures that there are no cycles; a cycle would cause non-termination, just as it would with is_segment. "  The first confusion is the definition: is the cycle defined in the directed sense or undirected? I assume we are talking about the second case. Then it is pretty clear that even if our checking function terminates, we cannot rule out the possibility that it contains an (undirected) cycle. Consider the simple case where we have a triangle, rooted at any vertex. It is not a valid binary search tree, but our function terminates.

title: Blotched AVL rotation example in class
body:
Earlier in class, the example I had in my notes of where a single rotation is not sufficient to restore the height invariant in an AVL tree after an insert, did not work out. Here's an actual example. Consider the AVL tree 
            40         /       \\     20            60   /    \\ 10      30
and let's insert 35: 
T':       => 40         /       \\     20            60   /    \\ 10      30           \\            35
Ok. We have a height invariant violation (indicated with "=>" and "<="). What happens if we rotate the tree right at 40? 
           20 <=         /       \\     10            40                 /    \\               30      60                 \\                  35
This doesn't work! We still have a violation, and doing a left rotation on 20 will get us back to the previous tree. We need to carry out a double-rotation, which amounts to first doing a left rotation at 20 (in the original tree, T') and then a right rotation at 40. Let's do it in steps: Rotate left at 20 (note that this is a node below the first violation) 
            => 40            /       \\         30           60       /   \\     20     35   / 10
Rotate right at 40 
          30       /        \\     20          40   /           /    \\ 10          35      60
Now we are back to a tree that respects the height invariant, a valid AVL tree. When to use each rotation? Single rotation: when the imbalance occurs in an outer subtree, i.e., and the symmetric case. You can see how it all works out with generic tree on the slides posted on the course web site (http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~15122/misc/avl.pdf) and (done in slightly different way) on the lecture notes for the AVL lecture. If you want to see how insertion works on concrete AVL trees, there are a number of animations on the web, for example http://www.cs.usfca.edu/~galles/visualization/AVLtree.html . If you want to try it out yourself in code, see the C0 implementation available on the course web site.

title: Written 8 2(c)
body:
Can someone please help me understand why the following code for my remove_from_chain does not work. I recieved the following feedback: "You are always returning a NULL pointer." I do not see how this function would always return a NULL pointer, especially in the case that p is not NULL to begin with. 
chain* remove_from_chain(chain* p, key k) {   chain* prev = p;   while (prev != NULL) {     chain* next = prev->next;     if (next != NULL && key_equiv(elem_key(next->data), k)) {       prev = next->next;     }     prev = next;   }   return p; }

title: Written 08 grading bug
body: We discovered a grading issue in task 2(c) of written 08: the rubric assumed each chain in the hash table H could contain multiple elements with the same key (only the first one of which would be returned by ht_lookup), but the precondition is_ht(H) prevented that. As a result, some people got 0.5 point deducted for not removing all elements with that key in the chain (first argument of remove_from_chain). We fixed this by: Changing the weight of the rubric item "Removes current element iff key is k" from 0.5 points to 1 pointRemoving the incorrect rubric item "Removes all elements with key k" Consequently, the people above are now getting an additional 0.5pt. This is already reflected in the grade forecaster. Sorry for the inconvenience.

title: bloom_new in bloom1
body:
When I try to compile bloom1, I get "attempt to dereference null pointer." I'm guessing that the error comes from these lines in the function bloom_new: 
  bloom_t* B_pointer = alloc(bloom_t);   (*B_pointer)->capacity = m;
I'm having a lot of trouble trying debugging this. Could someone help point me to the right direction? Thank you!

title: Clarification on bloom2 size
body: The writeup says bloom_new(n) creates a bloom filter whose data field is an array of n/32 integers. Wouldn't you end up with an effective table size smaller than (or equal to) the requested table size? And if n is less than 32, wouldn't it try to make an array of length 0? It should really be an array of 1 + n/32 integers, right?  On Autolab I keep failing the last test with the hint : Hint: bloom_new creates bloom_t with the requested limit   Which seems to me like it's saying bloom_new(n) should create a bloom filter with a data field of an array of n integers (effectively 32n bools) instead?

title: Written 08 grades
body:
Written assignment 08 is graded. The grades are posted on the course web page. Click on the "Grades" menu, authenticate, and you'll see your grades for this homework, and a projection for future assessments. This is a good way to get a sense of where you are headed in the course, and take action if it does not match your expectations. The "Participation" entry accounts for all quizzes and labs so far. Here are some statistics, normalized as percentages: 
Max    100.0% Min\t11.3% Avg     79.9% Median  84.8% StdDev  16.7
You can access your graded homework on Gradescope. There you will find you score together with feedback about what each of you did correctly and what you missed. Note: a few people are making submission really really close to the deadline. If Gradescope tells us it arrived past 9pm, even by a couple of seconds, that submission gets the 50% penalty. Is it worth to risk it to include that one last sentence? We do occasionally make mistakes. If you feel we incorrectly graded a question, you have 5 days from now to submit an appeal using the grade appeal procedure on the course web page. We will not consider email or oral requests.

bool get_bit(int[] A, int i) //@requires 0 <= i && i/32 < \\length(A); {   //represents which integer to look in and how many bits to right-shift    int indexofint = i / 32;   int bit = 31 - (i % 32);      //right shift to get desired bit   int result = (A[indexofint]) >> bit;   //make everything else on the left 0   result = result & 0x00000001;      //if bit is 1 then true, if 0 then false   return (result == 1); }    void set_bit(int[] A, int i) //@requires 0 <= i && i/32 < \\length(A);  //@ensures get_bit(A, i);  {   //represents which integer to look in and how many bits to right-shift    int indexofint = i / 32;   int bit = 31 - (i % 32);      //set bit   int result = ((A[indexofint]) >> bit) & (0x00000001);   result = result << bit;   A[indexofint] = (A[indexofint]) | result;  }

//Here is the autograder output Test bloom1, expect successful execution - good, this worked. *** PERFORMANCE SCORE: 45 *** ERROR: this does not match what we expected! *** This indicates something is wrong with your implementation.  //Here is some of my implementation  typedef struct bloom_filter bloom; struct bloom_filter {   bool[] data;   int capacity; // capacity == \\length(data) };  //hash_mul31 is from lab int hash_mul31(string s) {   if (string_length(s) == 0) return 0;   int res = 0;   char curr_char;   int curr_ascii;   int len = string_length(s);      for (int i = 0; i < len; i++)   //@loop_invariant i <= string_length(s);   {     curr_char = string_charat(s, i);     curr_ascii = char_ord(curr_char);     res = (res * 31) + curr_ascii;   }   return res; }  bool is_bloom(bloom* B)  //@requires B != NULL; //@requires \\length(B -> data) == B -> capacity; {   return ((B != NULL) && (B -> capacity > 0)); }  bloom* bloom_new(int table_size) //@requires table_size > 0; //@ensures is_bloom(\\result); {   bloom* B = alloc(bloom);   B -> capacity = table_size;   B -> data = alloc_array(bool, table_size);   return B; }  bool bloom_contains(bloom* B, string x)  //@requires is_bloom(B); {    int hash = hash_mul31(x);   int hash_index = abs((hash + 1) % (B -> capacity));      //@assert(hash_index >= 0);   //@assert(hash_index < B -> capacity);      return (B -> data[hash_index]);  }

title: Test case checker issues fixed
body:
As several of you noticed, the Bloom filter assignment was installed incorrectly on Autolab: the ungraded "Bloom Test Case Checker" instance was unavailable, and moreover what was available was not displaying scores for tasks 2-5. This is now fixed. Here's what you will now see on Autolab: and here's how to use them: Use Bloom Tests (UNGRADED) for checking your work for task 1. There are unlimited submissions and it will display a score only for task 1. To submit, you can either use the handin script from an andrew machine as follows 
handin bloomcheck bloom-test.c0
(see also README.txt), or you can use the web interface and submit the file bloomtesthandin.tgz generated as follows 
tar -czvf bloomtesthandin.tgz bloom-test.c0
Use Bloom Filters to submit your work for all tasks (1-5). This is the version that will be graded. You have a total of 5 unpenalized submissions for it. If you are one of the 6 students who made a submission to Bloom Filters before noon today (March 14th), please send me an email and I will delete those submissions (but I need your permission for this). Please do not make new submissions until the old ones are deleted.

title: Mid-semester grades
body: The mid-semester grades have been posted on S3 and will become visible on Monday (March 13th) at 4pm -- S3 makes it rather cumbersome to release grades ahead of their set schedule for a large class. The grades were based on written hw 1 to 7, programming hw 1 to 6 (style points for EXP included), on midterm 1, and on the participation points (labs and quizzes up to now). That amounted to 39.95% of the grades that are available in the course (all future hw and exams account for the rest). The letter grades were computed in a most naive way based on the grade-threshold table below (g >=92% is A, 92% < g <= 90% is A-, etc), where g is your cumulative grade on the items above scaled to 100%. This number g is also very close to the value the rightmost point of the thick red line in the grade forecaster. As you look at your mid-semester grade, there are a couple of important things to keep in mind: 60.05% of the points for the course are still for grabs. This means that if you did not do as well as you hoped for, there is plenty of opportunity for corrections.The mid-semester grade is rather optimistic. It does not account for the fact that, in general, students do much better in homework than in exams (and we had many more hw points than exam points so far). To get a more accurate sense of how you are doing, use the "what-if" section of the grade forecaster and plug your grade for midterm 1 (in percentages) in for midterm 2 and for the final. The updated red line will tell you where you are really headed. So, some will want to make corrections even if the posted mid-semester grade is their ultimate goal.The table below is NOT the way we will compute the course grades. This will be based on some kind of thresholds (still TBD) between letter grades and on your individual performance on the various parts of the course. Unlike the mid-semester grades, it won't be based on a rigid formula -- see course web site for further details. Also, just to dispel any lingering myth, this course is not curved (see note below for what "curving" implies and why you really don't want that. The table below shows the grade thresholds used to compute the mid-semester grades and a count of how many students got each letter grade. These numbers are also plotted on the chart.

title: How is 15-122 going?  Now with responses and comments
body: We have put together a brief survey to get a better sense of how things are going from your perspective. This will help us correct any issues for the rest of the term and improve future editions. The survey is anonymous, so please feel free to speak your mind. You can find it at: https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/LLPLNNN The survey will close on next Sunday night (March 19). [Disclaimer: there are a few things we won't be able to change, namely the topics 15-122 covers, and the expectations in terms of homework/exams -- those were set by the people who designed the course] Survey outcomes: First, thank to all of those who took the time to fill the survey! This input is really valuable for making 15-122 better. In fact, without feedback from you, we would not be able to know of certain things that need to get fixed. Below is a summary of responses, with some comments (in italics). What worked well? (In no particular order) programming hw, lectures, labs, office hours, recitations, Piazza, bonus, TAs, Gradescope, instructors, written hw. Given that this is pretty much all we do, it looks like everybody found something good in the course (although not everybody the same thing). What should be done better? Pretty much the same things that other said worked well, minus Piazza and Gradescope. This means everybody found something that can be improved.Participation points (more quizzes, lab points, points for recitation, ...) You shouldn't worry too much: (a) historically the vast majority of the class got the full 5% by the end of the semester, (b) there will be plenty more opportunities to earn participation points, (c) it's a tiny fraction of the total score for the course.Go over quizzes in class. Sure, why not?Assess how many students earn the "3rd lab point" and call it a "bonus point". How many students got 3 points in lab varied a lot throughout the semester, from a low of 8% to a high of 72% with an average of 40%. While this is fairly normal, we monitor the trends and make adjustments to labs to keep it more predictable. If that helps, you are free to view it as a bonus point.Written and programming hw are hard compared to what is covered in class. Of course! The lectures are meant to introduce building blocks and basic concepts, and do so in the limited time we have available. Assignments are meant to explore them further by combining them in sophisticated ways.Lectures and lecture notes are not an exact match. The two are very close but indeed there are some differences. One the one hand, we do want to expose you to different ways to approach the same concept, simply because different approaches resonate differently with different students -- use the one that best helps you learn. On the other hand, lectures are where we experiment with new ways to present some concepts, and if they work we later incorporate them into the lecture notes.Make 15-122 more like 15-112. Sorry, you graduated from that one already.Don't force us to go to specific lectures, we are college students! Blame (or thank) the fire marshal, not us! By law, we are not allowed to fit more people than the official capacity of a room. Regulating attendance is one way to make sure 400 people don't show up to the lecture/labs/recitations that are late in the day.Written/programming assignments are unclear. While this is not intentional, you will see that as you progress through your studies assignments will have less and less precise instructions. One reason is that as things get more complex, it is harder to spell everything out. A second reason is that the parts that are not fully spelled out can generally be inferred from the context or from what you have done so far. The most important reason, though, is that very little is fully spelled out in real life, and that's what we are preparing you for, in part.Keep the best Autolab submission rather than the last one. No objection to that, but Autolab does not support it and doing so manually would require many more resources than we have available. How is the pace of the course? Too fast: 17%A bit fast: 41%Just right: 31%A bit slow: 10%Too slow: 0% Any additional comments? Various expressions of love or dislike for this and that.More practice problems. There are a few at the end of the notes for each lectures and we will adding more. We can also give some at the end of class.More bonus problems. We are trying to find the right balance. Weaker students tend to find lots of bonus problems demoralizing, while stronger students love them. Some general comments: There are a few things mentioned above that we cannot change as individual instructors. These include the topics covered by the course and the performance expectations to pass the class. This impacts the kind and difficulty of the assignments and the pace of the course. Said this, the overall group of 15-122 instructors (not just the ones you see) review the course periodically and we are taking into account your feedback. There are also some things we will not change because, based on past experience, they lead to reduced learning and lower performance overall. These include a few things that some of you find unpalatable, like the very notion of a participation grade (even if ours is a small one), having written and programming assignment as separate hw, and the collaboration policy. Finally, there are the logistical challenges of managing one of the largest course on campus (15-122 was the largest class on campus last Fall; I haven't heard about this Spring yet). Many of our policies and procedures are dictated by this: heavy use of automation, strict rules, rare exceptions, etc. We don't have the luxury of being as accommodating as some of the other classes you have taken or are taking simply because we don't have the resources to do so (or we would have to significantly lower what you are getting out of this class, which we can't do).

bool is_dll_segment_ctn_pt(tbuf* B) {  //empty case  if (B->end->prev == B->start) return true;   for (dll* p = B->end; p !=B->start;p=p->prev){    if (p==B->cursor) return true;    }  return false; }
2. This function checks that B->start is in front of B->end 
bool is_seg(tbuf* B) {   for(dll* p = B->start; p != NULL; p = p->next){     if (p == B->end) return true;   }   return false; }
I think those two helper functions should cover all possible case with order swap, but it still won't pass autolab. Could somebody give me a hint?

title: Lecture 13: Question on client interface functions
body: I'd like to check my understanding for why we have functions in the client interface.  We want our library interface to have functions that enable general operations with hash tables (like checking it an elem is in it, making a new hash table, or adding an elem). Say in our library interface we have a helper function to get a hash value for an elem we want to add into the hash table, then we're limiting a client who uses our library interface to this one hash function. It's better for the client to have freedom in whatever hash function they want to use, so we make our library interface to be be general enough to allow for this.

Help during Spring break will be limited: We will answer Piazza posts, but not as quickly as we normally do.There won't be normal office hours, but some bored TAs may decide to show up to their office hours (if so, this will be posted on Piazza).  March 10th and 11th (this Friday and Saturday) are not part of Spring break, and neither is Sunday March 19th. title: tokens example from recitation
body: I'm still a little unclear about how the tokens model works for the example we did in recitation today where we incremented the limit by 1.5 instead of 2. So say we had an array that was:  |1|2|_|_|  Then we add in a 3 and 4, and our amortized cost is 4 tokens for each to do so.        ... ... |1|2|3|4|  Now, we resize and we spend a token to copy each element over:  .  .  . . |1|2|3|4|_|_|  Now we have 2 tokens saved up. Now say we want to add in some new elements 5 and 6 - so now we have spent those 2 tokens and then we spend 4 more.   .  .  . .  ... ...  |1|2|3|4| 5| 6|   Now when we copy into a new array, we get:   .  .  .  . .  .  |1|2|3|4|5|6|_|_|_|  but now we have 4 tokens left over. We can then spend those four tokens for writing each new one, and we have one more saved. So instead of paying 3*3 = 9 tokens, we can now spend only 9-4 = 5 tokens across the whole. So now we have spent 5 tokens. I thought that the whole point was that we were supposed to spend an amortized cost of 4 tokens each time?

title: Discussion on 2.1 (a)
body: The criteria is "We need to check that A and B are not NULL and nothing else." Why nothing else? If the two objects in both sides of "!=" operator have different types, there will be an error message and the program will not run properly; if "a" does not have field "end", the dereference a -> end will not be successful.    The condition "A and B are not NULL" is included in my answer, and I justified it, so I should at least get some points. The grader may assume I was overthinking it, but I think I should think about all the possible aspects because the question does not state "be precise" or anything like that.   Thus, I request a regrade on my question 2.1(a).

Why is it that when comparing ints, the * is required, but when comparing NULL, the * is not allowed? If p is a null pointer, shouldn't p be pointing to NULL (and we would have to look at what p is pointing at, therefore using the *)? Thanks!

title: Written 4 Problem 3 (c) Rubric/Common Mistakes
body:
PLEASE READ THIS BEFORE SUBMITTING A REGRADE REQUEST FOR PROBLEM 3 (C) While grading Problem 3 (c), we realized that the rubric items on gradescope did not fully cover all of the possible combinations of code that could arise in responses, so we were forced to make certain (somewhat hidden) changes to how we were grading Problem 3 (c) based on the loop invariants. Therefore, we decided to post a general outline of how we graded this problem. Point 2 on the gradescope rubric is received either if Point 1 was received AND the postcondition given was safe or if Point 1 was not received AND there was an explicit check of safety of array accesses in the postcondition. Note that this means that if no array access was made in the postcondition and you did not receive point 1 it is impossible to receive points for point 2.Point 7 on the gradescope rubric is received either if Point 6 was received AND the postcondition given was safe or if Point 6 was not received AND there was an explicit check of safety of array accesses in the postcondition. Note that this means that if no array access was made in the postcondition and you did not receive point 6 it is impossible to receive points for point 7.The correct loop invariants were anything equivalent to ge_seg(x, A, 0, lo) and lt_seg(x, A, hi, n). If you had something different, this changed how exactly we graded the rest of the problem. Specifically If the loop invariants were too weak (for instance, using ge_seg(x, A, 0, lo) and le_seg(x, A, hi, n), there was a 0.25 point deduction applied to the problem, and no credit could be given for Point 6 on the Gradescope rubric. If the loop invariants were unsafe, syntactically incorrect, self-contradictory or impossible to satisfy, no credit was given for points 3-6 regardless of if they matched the rubric.If the loop invariants were something else, they were handled on a case by case basis. In general though, we graded points 4-7 in context of the loop invariants. It was possible for points 4/6 to be exactly what was written on the rubric, but not to receive points due to them not making sense in context of the loop invariants Some Mistakes to avoid (Some were common) Some people used \\length(A) instead of n in the postcondition. Be careful doing this, as in many cases this could result in an incorrect postcondition. For instance, consider the below array, where x = 15122 and n = 3. If our postcondition was ... && (\\result == \\length(A)-1 || A[\\result + 1] > x. In that case, a result of 2 is the correct answer, but would violate the ensures statement! (A[result + 1] < x)
1000010100151221010010000
A lot of people missed Point 5 because of an incorrect negation. Be careful - !(A && B) $$\ eq$$ !A. Instead, !(A && B) = !A || !B.If your code barely fits (or doesn't fit) in the space provided, it likely is overly complicated. Make your TAs happy, and increase your chances at getting a point, by simplifying your code! This goes for your proofs as well Test your code! A lot of people could have avoided missed points if they just tried it out to see if it worked Note: This will likely be the only time we will post the full rubric/common mistakes for any homework

title: Style Question (White Space)
body: Whitespace - Don t make your code terribly cramped up so that it s hard to read. Use blank lines to separate unrelated blocks of code and to give your program a structure. Within a line use spaces to to separate characters but stay consistent. Use the same amount of space on either side of an infix operator (either 0 or 1 spaces), do 2+3 or 2 + 3, not 2+ 3. Use spaces around parentheses: (2 + 3) * (4 + 5) is better than (2 + 3)*(4 + 5). Avoid trailing whitespace at the end of lines.  I didn't get graded down for proper use of white space but I did have a TA mention that I shouldn't have whitespace. I was wondering what the official policy is?  Sterling

Information about the midterm
body: Some information about the upcoming midterm: It is taking place on Tuesday February 21st as follows (building map): Students in lecture 1: 9:00-10:20am Sections A/AA, B/BB: DH A302 Sections C/CC, D/DD, E/EE, F/FF, G/GG: DH 2315 Students in lecture 2: 10:30-11:50am Sections H/HH: PH A18B Sections I/II: PH 226C Sections J/JJ: PH 235B Sections K/KK, L/LL, M/MM, N/NN: DH 2315 Students with accommodations: I will email you shortly. If you are expecting accommodations and you did not get an email, email me immediately at iliano@cmu.edu Everybody must bring his/her student ID. You MUST arrive on time if you arrive late you will not be given extra time. The exam has a duration of 80 minutes. The topics are pretty much everything we have covered in class since the beginning of the term to Thursday February 16th (included). Looking at the contents of the practice midterms (see course web page), written assignments, labs and recitations will provide you with a good idea of what to expect. We will ask you to write some C0 code, but we won't be picky about minor issues of syntax. We will take points off, however, for invalid contracts. All you can have with you is a single double-sided 8.5" x 11" handwritten cheat sheet: the exam will contain nothing that can be just looked up in your notes or in the handouts, and we will provide you with all the information you need to solve each question. Writing a 1-page cheat sheet is an incredibly effective way of reviewing concepts even if you never end up looking at it. There will be a review session on Sunday from 6 to 8pm in PH 100. If you have any doubts, that's a good opportunity to get them resolved.

title: Big O Question
body: So let's say we have this code from the lecture notes.  Why is the worst case number of comparisons 3n and not 3n + 1?  Here's what I got:  The loop will iterate n times. So Lines 12 and 13 will get checked n times each. But the loop guard will get checked n + 1 times. Let's say n = 4. The loop guard gets checked for i = 0, i = 1, i = 2, i = 3, and i = 4, where it will become false. So n + 1 comparisons In total, n + 1 + n + n = 3n + 1.

body:
int main() {      string[] vocab = parse_tokens("This is a test");     st(vocab,0,4);     assert(is_sorted(vocab,0,4));     int[] freq = alloc_array(int,4);     freq[0] = 4;freq[1] = 4;freq[2] = 2; freq[3] = 1;     string corpus = "texts/scott_tweet.txt";     assert(count_vocab(vocab, freq,4,corpus,true)==1);     assert(false);     sort_by_freq(vocab,freq,4);     assert(vocab == parse_tokens("test a This is"));  return 5; }
When I try to compile the test function, the -d flag says that the requires statement (//@requires is_sorted(A,0,n)) for binsearch is failing. title: question 3c
body: For the blanks in lines 23-26, I am a bit confused on how this binary search would work for some specific examples.  For array A = [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7] where x = 4 and n = 8. If I put the conditional on line 23 as A[mid] <= x and the assert statement on line 25 as A[mid] > x, on the first iteration, mid would be 4. A[4] = 4, which is <= x. So lo = mid + 1 = 5. But that would mean that the loop would continue to search from indices 5 to hi, which disregards the fact that A[mid] = x.  If I instead switch where the equals goes to. So the conditional on line 23 would instead be A[mid] < x and the assert statement on line 25 would be A[mid] >= x. For array A = [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 4, 4, 4] where x = 4 and n = 8, on the first iteration of the loop, mid would be 4. A[4] = 4, which is not < x so the loop would go to the else statement (the assert statement verifies that A[4] >= x). So, hi = mid = 4. But that would mean that the loop would continue to search from indices 0 to 4, which wouldn't find the last occurrence which is in the part of the array from indices 4 to 7.  I can't quite understand how to find the last occurrence of x in these cases with the given statements that follow the conditionals in the loop.

My question is, can we consider n to be 0 as best case, or do we have to create a best-case scenario for any n?

title: accounting for constants when finding closed form expression
body: Hi, how do we account for constants when finding closed form expressions? For example if I have: for ( loop runs n times ) {     int j = 0     if (j > 1):         do something } Would this be T(3n) because it executes 3 lines of code n times?  Or for example: for ( loop runs n times) {     do something     for (loop runs n^2 + 2n times) {        do something     } } Would this be T(n^3 + 2n + n) because the loop does n^2 + 2n + 1 commands n times?  Thanks!

title: Mergesort
body: From mergesort.c0 file:  38 void sort(int[] A, int lo, int hi)  39 //@requires 0 <= lo && lo <= hi && hi <= \\length(A);  40 //@ensures is_sorted(A, lo, hi);  41 {  42   if (hi-lo <= 1) return;  43   int mid = lo + (hi-lo)/2;  44   sort(A, lo, mid); //@assert is_sorted(A, lo, mid);  45   sort(A, mid, hi); //@assert is_sorted(A, mid, hi);  46   merge(A, lo, mid, hi);  47   return;  48 }  I'm confused as to how the @assert statements work in lines 44 & 45.  Let's say we are sorting the array [9 7 5 3 1 8 6 4 2 0] What do we end up by the end of line 44? [9] [7] [5] [3] [1] [8 6 4 2 0]? [1 3 5 7 9] [8 6 4 2 0]? [1 3 5 7 9 8 6 4 2 0]? ...? Does the assertion pass because we broke the array into "size 1" elements or does it pass because it actually gets sorted? I thought the sorting process doesn't happen until merge gets called in line 46...

body: int binsearch(string x, string[] A, int n) //@requires 0 <= n && n <= \\length(A); //@requires is_sorted(A, 0, n); /*@ensures (-1 == \\result && !is_in(x, A, 0, n))          || ((0 <= \\result && \\result < n)             && string_equal(A[\\result], x)); @*/  C0 interpreter (coin) 0.3.3 'Nickel' (r590, Sun Oct  9 16:37:15 EDT 2016) Type `#help' for help or `#quit' to exit. --> string[] a=alloc_array(string,3); a is 0x28C48A0 (string[] with 3 elements) --> a[0]="a"; a[0] is "a" (string) --> a[1]="b"; a[1] is "b" (string) --> a[2]="c"; a[2] is "c" (string) --> binsearch("c",a,3); -1 (int) --> binsearch("c",a,4); 2 (int)   when n=3, it should return 2(int), but it returns -1(int). title: manipulate issues fixed
body: For some of those who carried out (optional) task 5, Autolab was working fine but their manipulated image was not showing properly in the scoreboard.  This issue is now fixed -- read on if you want to know more about it.  The autograder was correctly generating the image (as you could see from the bottom of the Autolab output -- that long string of random character is an encoded version of your image), but process that places that encoded image on the scoreboard accepts images up to only some maximum size (which is documented nowhere).  All along, the output of your manipulate was resized so that it fit in a 180x180 pixel square.  That worked fine except for those who output a square image.  For those, the image was beyond the maximum size and Autolab wouldn't display it.  I changed the setting so that it now fits a 150x150 pixel square, and that works for almost everybody (for 1 person that was still too much and I've since made it a bit smaller).

title: Stable sorting
body:
In lecture, we classified sorting algorithms based on whether they were fast or slow and based on whether they were processing the array in-place (i.e., they did not need to allocate a new array) or not. Another useful property is whether they are stable. Stability makes sense when you are sorting not just a number but a record (e.g., your iTunes collection or student grades). Let's take that as an example: say I have a spreadsheet with your andrew IDs and your homework grades. Most of the time it is sorted by andrew ID (that makes entering grades faster), but after each hw is graded it is useful to sort it by grade so to see who did well and who needs help. When I do that, what happens to the andrew IDs?
    They can remain in the same order for each grade (e.g., the andrew IDs of everybody who got 10 are still in order).They end up in shuffled, thereby losing the order.
A sorting algorithm that guarantees (1) is stable: entries with the same sorting value remain sorted. How do the sorting algorithms we examined fare? Here's a summary:
Fast?In-place?Stable?
Selection sortNO!Yes Yes
Insertion SortNO!Yes Yes
Merge sort YesNO!Yes
Quick sortMostlyYesNO!
Challenge questions: What does find_min need to guarantee for selection sort to be stable?What needs to be guaranteed for merge sort to be stable?Why is quick sort not stable

title: Bug on Task 3
body:
Hi, I wasn't sure if I could post this on here... but I have an error saying I am indexing out of bounds on my rotate function and I cannot seem to find what I am doing wrong and I have been at this for more than 3 hours. I'm having a hard time debugging with print statements, so I was wondering if there is an obvious mistake that you guys can see, I know the indexing out of bounds is occurring from one of the functions in the nested for loop, but I am not sure why it would index out of bounds because my i and j should be restricted. Here is my code, with my helper function: 
pixel[] rotate90(pixel[] pixels, int width, int height) //@requires 0 <= width && 0 <= height; {     pixel[] rotation = alloc_array(pixel, width*height);     int index = 0;     for (int i=width - 1; i >= 0;)     {         for (int j=0; j < height; j++)         {             rotation[index] = pixels[get_index(j, i, width, height)];             index ++;          }         i --;     }     return rotation; }  pixel[] rotate(pixel[] pixels, int width, int height) //@requires is_valid_imagesize(width, height); //@requires width == height; //@ensures \\length(\\result) == (width+height)*(width+height); //@ensures \\result != pixels; {     int array_length = (width+height)*(width+height);     pixel[] A = alloc_array(pixel, array_length);     pixel[] rotation_1 = rotate90(pixels, 2, 2);     pixel[] rotation_2 = rotate90(rotation_1, 2, 2);     pixel[] rotation_3 = rotate90(rotation_2, 2, 2);     int w = width;     int h = height;     int index = 0;     for (int i=0; i < height;){         for (int j=0; j < width; j++){             A[index] = rotation_1[get_index(i, j, w, h)];             A[index+w] = pixels[get_index(i, j, w, h)];             A[index+(2*w*h)] = rotation_2[get_index(i, j, w, h)];             A[index+(2*w*h+w)] = rotation_3[get_index(i, j, w, h)];             index ++;          }         i ++;     }     return A; }
Any advice would be really appreciated!

The writeUp says we should guarantee safe array access to get the 3 points for programming 3. When I look at my code in rotation.c0. 
 41            int row = get_row(i,sz,sz);  42            int col = get_column(i,sz,sz);  43            int newRow = 0;  44            int newCol = 0;  45            int pos = 0;  46            if (dir == 0){  47               newRow = col;  48               newCol = sz-1-row;  49               pos = get_index(newRow,newCol,sz,sz);  50               newPix[pos] = thisPixel;}  51            else if (dir ==1){  52               newRow = sz-1-row;  53               newCol = sz-1-col;  54               pos = get_index(newRow,newCol,sz,sz);  55               newPix[pos] = thisPixel;}  56            else{  57               newRow = sz-1-col;  58               newCol = row;  59               pos = get_index(newRow,newCol,sz,sz);  60               newPix[pos] = thisPixel;}}

title: images: is_valid_imagesize
body:
Hi, I'm working on writing the preconditions described in the imageutil.c0 file, copied here: 
// Checks whether width and height are valid dimensions. To be valid // dimensions, width and height must be strictly positive, and // multiplying width*height must not cause overflow.
According to the C0 tutorial page on Ints, there are only two cases for overflow - dividing or modding the minimal integer by -1. (Although, wouldn't multiplying int_min by -1 also cause overflow?) If my first precondition makes sure that width > 0 and height > 0, then wouldn't width*height never cause overflow, because they would never be int_min or -1? So the only precondition needed is width > 0 and height > 0, and the overflow one described is redundant? EDIT: I realized the function is already written, so no preconditions necessary. So I guess my edited question is about the line here: 
width <= int_max() / height
Why is width*height <= int_max() required? (Since C0 tutorial says multiplication will never overflow?) And is there a reason that int_max() / height is on the right instead of writing "width*height <= int_max()", or is that stylistic?

title: Loop invariant preservation
body: I am wondering whether exiting a loop because of return statements would violate the preservation of loop invariant. By definition, a loop invariant is supposed to hold before and after the loop iteration and I think it is inappropriate for a loop to have return statements inside because that could lead to safety issues since the loop does not exit appropriately. (Does not exit because the loop guards evaluate to false). Therefore, we cannot guarantee anything about the postcondition anymore. (NOT loop guard AND loop invariants).  This question is related to Written 3(a),3(b). Shall we just assume that the if conditional never evaluates to true so that the function never returns during loop iterations? (which means that x is never found in the array.)

When looking at the documentation, it looks as if gt_seg and le_seg checks to see if the value given (x) is,greater than or less than or equal to, respectively, A[i] where i is an index starting at lo, and going to, without checking the hi.  Another way to phrase my question, when you are checking all the indexes of a set that are in the set of [0,0) or [n,n) do you check A[0] or A[n]? or does it not check?

title: pixels: test_quantize
body:
Hi, I seem to have a bug in my test_quantize function, where I did not catch "returns wrong answers". My tests included different q levels (0, 2,4, and 7), as well as a different alpha value to make sure it did not change. Code here: 
void test_quantize() {     pixel_t p1 = quantize(make_pixel(0xFF, 0xFF, 0xFF, 0xFF), 4);     assert(get_alpha(p1) == 0xFF);     assert(get_red(p1)   == 0xF0);     assert(get_green(p1) == 0xF0);     assert(get_blue(p1)  == 0xF0);      pixel_t p2 = quantize(make_pixel(0xFF, 0xFF, 0xFF, 0xFF), 0);     assert(get_alpha(p2) == 0xFF);     assert(get_red(p2)   == 0xFF);     assert(get_green(p2) == 0xFF);     assert(get_blue(p2)  == 0xFF);      pixel_t p3 = quantize(make_pixel(0xFF, 0xFF, 0xFF, 0xFF), 7);     assert(get_alpha(p3) == 0xFF);     assert(get_red(p3)   == 128);     assert(get_green(p3) == 128);     assert(get_blue(p3)  == 128);      pixel_t p4 = quantize(make_pixel(0xFF, 0xFF, 0xFF, 0xFF), 2);     assert(get_alpha(p4) == 0xFF);     assert(get_red(p4)   == 0xFC);     assert(get_green(p4) == 0xFC);     assert(get_blue(p4)  == 0xFC);      pixel_t p5 = quantize(make_pixel(0x0F, 0xFF, 0xFF, 0xFF), 2);     assert(get_alpha(p5) == 0x0F);     assert(get_red(p5)   == 0xFC);     assert(get_green(p5) == 0xFC);     assert(get_blue(p5)  == 0xFC); }
Since I'm missing some tests, I was wondering if that meant that I would have to test all possible q levels [0, 8), or if I'm missing something else. I was thinking that usually unit testing shouldn't be testing all possible inputs, but since there are only 7 here, that's what my mistake is? I got 3/4 points for this function.

body:
1 /* The pixel type and an interface to pixels */   2    3 typedef int pixel;       // Library (concrete) view of a pixel   4 typedef pixel pixel_t;   // Client  (abstract) view of a pixel   5    6 // Returns the red component of the given pixel p.   7  // POSTCONDITION: returned value is between 0 and 255, inclusive.   8  int get_red(pixel p)   9   10  //@ensures 0 <= \\result && \\result <= 255;  11  {  12  if (p == 255){  13     return p;  14 }  15 else  16 {  17     return p >> 16 &  0x00000011;  18 }  19   20  // Returns the green component of the given pixel p.  21  // POSTCONDITION: returned value is between 0 and 255, inclusive.  22  int get_green(pixel p)  23  //@ensures 0 <= \\result && \\result <= 255;  24  {  25  return -1  ? p == 255 : p >> 8 & 0x00000011;  26  }  27   28  // Returns the blue component of the given pixel p.  29  // POSTCONDITION: returned value is between 0 and 255, inclusive.  30  int get_blue(pixel p)  31 //@ensures 0 <= \\result && \\result <= 255;  32  {  33  return p & 0x00000011;  34  }  35   36  // Returns the alpha component of the given pixel p.  37  // POSTCONDITION: returned value is between 0 and 255, inclusive.  38 int get_alpha(pixel p)  39 //@ensures 0 <= \\result && \\result <= 255;  40  {  41  return p >> 24 & 0x00000011;  42  }  43   44  // Returns an int representing an RGB pixel consisting of the given  45  // alpha, red, green and blue intensity values.  46  // PRECONDITION: all intensity values must be between 0 and 255,  47  // inclusive.  48  pixel make_pixel(int alpha, int red, int green, int blue)  49  //@requires 0 <= alpha && 0 <= red && 0 <= green && 0 <= blue && alpha <= 255 && red <= 255 && green <= 255 && blue <=255;  50  {  51  return 0x00000000 & alpha << 24 & red << 16 & green << 8 & blue;  52  }

title: Three questions
body: 1. When we are reasoning over the postconditions, loop invariants and loop guards are all the information that we can rely on, right? On page 8 of lecture note 4, why it says "If we exit from the loop because A[i] > x, we also know that A[i 1] < x so x cannot be in the array since it is sorted.". (BTW, A[i] > x written inside the loop). If loop guards and loop invariants are all the information that we can rely on, does it mean that we can deduce the loop invariants based on the postconditions?  2. Is there any perfect example to illustrate the difference?  3."Ensures" require the variable to be unchanged by the function. Does "requires" also have the same requirement?

title: Written 02 grades
body:
Written assignment 02 is graded. The grades are posted on the course web page. Click on the "Grades" menu, authenticate, and you'll see your grades for this homework, and a projection for future assessments. This is a good way to get a sense of where you are headed in the course, and take action if it does not match your expectations. The "Participation" entry accounts for all quizzes and labs so far. Here are some statistics, normalized as percentages: 
Max    100.0% Min\t23.5% Avg     77.3% Median  81.5% StdDev  14.2
You can access your graded homework on Gradescope. There you will find you score together with feedback about what each of you did correctly and what you missed. We do occasionally make mistakes. If you feel we incorrectly graded a question, you have 5 days from now to submit an appeal using the grade appeal procedure on the course web page. We will not consider email or oral requests.

title: Academic integrity rules for repeat students
body: Several people who took, or at least started taking, this class in a past semester submitted homework solutions that they took verbatim from submissions they made that semester. Be aware that doing so is a violation of academic integrity -- even if it was your own work. Doing so is also not very smart: If you are just copying an old solution, you are not learning anything, and if you are not learning anything chances are that you are going to do badly in the course.We can tell. So, what to do? Archive your old work and never look at it this semester, with the possible (and only) exception of exam practice. Some people asked "What if I end up writing the same thing because I did it recently?" The likelihood of that is infinitesimal: that's simply not the way people's brain work.

void test_quantize() {   for (int i = 0; i < 8; i++)   {     pixel_t p1 = make_pixel(0xFF, 0xFF, 0xFF, 0xFF);     pixel_t p1_q = quantize(p1, i);     int r = (get_red(p1) >> i) << i;     int g = (get_green(p1) >> i) << i;     int b = (get_blue(p1) >> i) << i;     pixel_t p1_check = make_pixel(get_alpha(p1), r, g, b);     assert(get_alpha(p1_check) == get_alpha(p1_q));     assert(get_red(p1_check) == get_red(p1_q));     assert(get_green(p1_check) == get_green(p1_q));     assert(get_blue(p1_check) == get_blue(p1_q));      pixel_t p2 = make_pixel(0x00, 0x00, 0x00, 0x00);     pixel_t p2_q = quantize(p2, i);     r = (get_red(p2) >> i) << i;     g = (get_green(p2) >> i) << i;     b = (get_blue(p2) >> i) << i;     pixel_t p2_check = make_pixel(0x00, r, g, b);     assert(get_alpha(p2_check) == get_alpha(p2_q));     assert(get_red(p2_check) == get_red(p2_q));     assert(get_green(p2_check) == get_green(p2_q));     assert(get_blue(p2_check) == get_blue(p2_q));      pixel_t p3 = make_pixel(0x0E, 0x0E, 0x0E, 0x0E);     pixel_t p3_q = quantize(p3, i);     r = (get_red(p3) >> i) << i;     g = (get_green(p3) >> i) << i;     b = (get_blue(p3) >> i) << i;     pixel_t p3_check = make_pixel(0x0E, r, g, b);     assert(get_alpha(p3_check) == get_alpha(p3_q));     assert(get_red(p3_check) == get_red(p3_q));     assert(get_green(p3_check) == get_green(p3_q));     assert(get_blue(p3_check) == get_blue(p3_q));   } }

title: Fixing coin command not found error when you ssh into andrew machines
body:
If the coin command does not work when you ssh into an andrew machine and you have set up your environment properly (http://c0.typesafety.net/tutorial/Setting-up-your-environment.html), the potential problem may be that you have an existing .bash_profile. If a .bash_profile exists, then Bash will not read .bash_login. Therefore, open up the file $HOME/.bash_profile and add the following line 
source ~/.bashrc
into your .bash_profile. You can then either restart the shell, relogin, or just type in source ~/.bashrc for now, and coin should work on subsequent logins.

title: Tips on Reasoning about Code
body:
A common question among students each semester is "Can I use -------- to justify this statement? What kind of statements am I allowed to make?" This post is an attempt to clarify how we reason about code and structure our proofs in 15-122. There are two kinds of reasoning that we use in 15-122: logical reasoning and operational reasoning.
Logical reasoning is using what we know to be true to prove certain properties about code. Operational reasoning is drawing conclusions about how things change when certain lines of code are run.
Probably the best way to see the difference between these two types of reasoning is with examples. When we say things like this, we're using logical reasoning: "we know x > 0 from the loop guard""y is not modified in the loop""on line 5, we know z % 4 == 0 because we must have entered an if (z % 4 == 0) {...} statement" But when we say things like this, we're using operational reasoning: "after an iteration of the loop, i' = i - 1""x is strictly decreasing""we know x < 0 because x > 0 by the loop guard and x = -x by line 5" It's a common misconception that operational reasoning is always bad and should never be used. In fact, operational reasoning is often necessary to prove the correctness of functions. However, operational reasoning is more difficult and prone to error than logical reasoning, since you need to consider all of the possible effects any statement could have. Because of this, we want to limit our use of operational reasoning to the smallest chunks of code possible. In particular, it's very difficult to reason about multiple iterations of a loop at once, so you should never make statements like "the loop runs y times and x=0 initially, so x=y when the loop exits." In 15-122, operational reasoning should only be used to prove preservation of loop invariants and loop termination. Finally, to clarify an important point for written 2: An assertion is supported if we can prove it's always true using only logical reasoning.

title: >> Operator Question

So would we need to prove that we actually enter the loop? Also, for proving preservation, do we also get to assume that the loop guard is true in addition to the loop invariant?

title: Installing cc0 locally on macOS
body:
I've seen a few people struggling to install cc0 locally on macOS so I made a homebrew formula to do this. Here's how to use it:
    (If you don't have homebrew) Install homebrew brew.shOpen up terminal and run this: 
    brew install homebrew/dupes/zlib gyf304/cc0/cc0
    Done! Try cc0 to see if it works.
If you have any problem with the formula, post a follow-up discussion here and I will try to help.

title: Transferring files between AFS and local machine
body:
In order to work on assignments via SSH, you'll often need to transfer files between your computer and AFS storage (for example, when you first download a handout, or if you are transferring a file to your computer to submit to autolab). Though this can be achieved with the command scp, it is often easier to manage using a gui-based ftp frontend. For this, we recommend FileZilla, which is available on all common platforms. Some setup instructions (These instructions are based on the Windows version, so please let me know if your experience differs on Mac or Linux):
    Install the Filezilla Client (Note: the installer will also ask to install the Ad-Aware Browser, which you may want to opt out of)Enter the hostname "sftp://unix.andrew.cmu.edu" as well as your andrewid and password. Leave 'Port' blank.Click 'Quickconnect'.Under File>"Copy current connection...", save this connection. In the future you can connect by clicking the dropdown 'Site Manager' menu below the 'file' menu and selecting the connection name.On the left side of your screen, there is a file browser for your computer, and on the right side of your screen, there is a file browser for AFS storage. You can drag and drop files or directories from one side or the other to copy them.
As a reminder, the academic integrity policy requires that you take steps to protect your work against plagiarism. Your work on AFS should be kept exclusively in your private directory (anywhere else, it is publicly visible). If you keep your work on your computer, it should be password-protected.

title: Laptop setup office hours
body: If you need help setting up your laptop to work on assignments, we will have a laptop setup session on Wednesday from 4:30 to 6:30 in GHC 8102. This is will allow you to work remotely (either by installing C0 on your laptop or by setting up ssh to login to a Unix machine). Note that you can go at any time between 4:30 and 6:30 (so don't all come at 4:30). You can also set up your laptop yourself by following the instructions at http://c0.typesafety.net/tutorial/C0-at-CMU.html . See also Piazza postings @8, @9 and @10. A third way is to go to one of the alternate setup labs (see @18) and ask a TA to help once you've done the lab. TO CLARIFY -- There are two things you need to do this week: 1) Complete Lab 1 (the "setup lab"). You must either go to one of the lab classrooms during your scheduled time on Friday, or go to one of the alternate lab sessions (see @18). 2) Set up your laptop to connect to the Andrew servers. This can be done on your own using the instructions on Piazza (@8, @9, @10), at the laptop setup office hours (above), or during your setup lab (see @18).

title: Alternate setup lab
body: The first lab of the semester (the "setup lab") is where you get to practice using Unix, editing and running C0 files, and submitting to Gradescope/Autolab. The writeup and handout are on Autolab, and also here for your convenience: http://cs.cmu.edu/~15122/misc/lab01-writeup.pdfhttp://cs.cmu.edu/~15122/misc/lab01-handout.tgz This lab is exceptionally taking place on Friday this week in the CS clusters (GHC 5207, 5208, 5210). Many of you will want to get that practice sooner than that so that you can feel more confident working on the first written homework. Therefore, we are scheduling additional setup labs Wednesday and Thursday from 6:30 to 8:30 in the CS clusters. If you want to take advantage of them, just show up, notify a TA and go to a free computer (you may need to wait since there is a limited number of computers). Once you're done, you can also step aside and work on setting up your laptop (see also next post). Note that you can go at any time between 6:30 and 8:30 (so don't all come at the same time). If you decide to go to one of these additional sessions, you don't need to go to the regular lab on Friday. The setup lab is not graded (you don't earn points for it). Other labs are however -- see how it works on the web site. TO CLARIFY -- There are two things you need to do this week: 1) Complete Lab 1 (the "setup lab"). You must either go to one of the lab classrooms during your scheduled time on Friday, or go to one of the alternate lab sessions (above). 2) Set up your laptop to connect to the Andrew servers. This can be done on your own using the instructions on Piazza (@8, @9, @10), at the laptop setup office hours (see @19), or during your setup lab (above).

title: Enrollment, homework, and more
body: If you are reading this, you have successfully enrolled in Piazza. Congratulations! As said in class, we use Autolab and Gradescope for homework distribution and submission: If you were on the roster of this class 10 minutes ago, you are now registered on Autolab (that's where the writeups for all assignments, labs and recitations will be posted and where you submit programming assignments).You need to self-register on Gradescope (that's where written hw gets submitted). To do so, go to https://gradescope.com and sign up using YOUR ANDREW ADDRESS (no gmail or other email addresses) and entry code 937B39. (These instructions are also part of the setup lab.) Written homework 1 is now posted -- you can get started. It is due next Monday, at 9pm. (In the future, we won't use Piazza to announce when new hw are posted: they come up automatically as per the table on the course web page -- http://cs.cmu.edu/~15122 .) I forgot to mention in class why we have so many assignments (1 written and 1 programming each week most weeks -- sounds crazy!). In the distant past, they used to be combined as one assignment due each week. What happened was that some, well many, students spent most of their time on the programming part and did what they could on the written part in the 10 minutes before the deadline -- bad for learning and bad for grades. That's why we decided to split them and have different deadlines. We observe that the most successful students do them at the same time, going back and forth between written and programming -- and of course they start well ahead of the deadline. Good luck in 15-122, and if you have questions, come talk to us!

title: Laptop Setup for Windows
body:
If you have a Windows computer, follow these steps to set it up to connect to the Andrew system. If you need help, come to one of the setup sessions this week. For Mac, see @8. For Linux, see @9. 1) Download and install MobaXterm Home Edition (Installer edition), then restart your computer. 2) Open MobaXterm and click the "Session" button in the top left corner of the window. 3) Select "SSH" as the session type. 4) Enter "unix.andrew.cmu.edu" as the Remote host, click the checkbox for "Specify username", and enter your andrew id in the field. 5) Click "Ok" to connect via SSH, and enter your password when prompted. You may opt to save your password. 6) Check to make sure that X forwarding is working properly by running this command: 
eog ~rjsimmon/public/couch.jpg &
After a few seconds (be patient!), you should see a window appear with a picture of a couch. If that works, you're all set up! In the future, double-click the "unix.andrew.cmu.edu" session in the Saved sessions menu whenever you want to connect. If you're getting errors or having trouble, ask a TA at a setup session.

title: Laptop Setup for Linux
body:
If you have a Linux computer, follow these steps to set it up to connect to the Andrew system. If you need help, come to one of the setup sessions this week. For Mac, see @8. For Windows, see @10. 1) Open a Terminal window and use the following command to connect via SSH: 
ssh -X YOURANDREWID@unix.andrew.cmu.edu
2) Check to make sure that X forwarding is working properly by running this command: 
eog ~rjsimmon/public/couch.jpg &
After a few seconds (be patient!), you should see a window appear with a picture of a couch. If that works, you're all set up! Just use the command from step 1 whenever you want to connect. If you're getting errors or having trouble, ask a TA at a setup session.

title: Laptop Setup for Mac
body:
If you have a Mac, follow these steps to set up your personal computer to connect to the Andrew system. If you need help, come to one of the setup sessions this week. For Linux, see @9. For Windows, see @10. 1) Download and install XQuartz, then restart your computer. 2) Open a Terminal window and use the following command to connect via SSH: 
ssh -Y YOURANDREWID@unix.andrew.cmu.edu
If that doesn't work, try replacing the -Y with -X. 3) Check to make sure that XQuartz is working properly by running this command: 
eog ~rjsimmon/public/couch.jpg &
After a few seconds (be patient!), you should see a window appear with a picture of a couch. If that works, you're all set up! Just use the command from step 2 whenever you want to connect. If you're getting errors or having trouble, ask a TA at a setup session.
